description.narrative: Cost Increase to existing project to reduce exploitative child labor in sugarcane growing areas through the provision of direct educational services and sustainable livelihood services; supporting national institutions to improve policies, programs, and delivery of education, social protection, and sustainable livelihood services; raising awareness and ensuring long-term sustainability.

title.narrative: Closing The Child Labor And Forced Labor Evidence Gap: Impact Evaluations

description.narrative: To implement a randomized control trial impact evaluation of a Government of the Philippines' program that aims to reduce child labor through the provision of livelihood services to families of child laborers.

title.narrative: BuildCA2P: Building Capacity, Awareness, Advocacy and Programs Project

description.narrative: The BuildCA2P Project works to build the capacity of Filipino civil society to more effectively detect and combat child labor and other labor abuses in the crop agricultural sector in Mindanao, Philippines. It leverages partnerships with academic and advocacy organizations to build a grassroots movement, empower vulnerable families, connect survivors to grievance mechanisms and services, and reduce the risk that children will be harmed by performing hazardous work in agriculture.

activity-date.narrative: Date unavailable. Calculated start date is the earliest transaction date

title.narrative: Office of Child Labor, Forced Labor, and Human Trafficking (OCFT) - Against Child Exploitation (ACE) Project

description.narrative: ACE seeks to strengthen governments and communities in Asia to address the worst forms of child labor, including the online sexual exploitation of children, and promote acceptable conditions of work through a unified and participatory approach, beginning with action in the Philippines.

description.narrative: The project aims to improve adherence with Philippine labor standards, focusing on the agricultural, fishing, and mining sectors in rural communities, and on women in the same rural sectors.
